sections.heading: Handling the Very Big & Very Small
sections.content: In S4 Algebra, we move beyond basic multiplication. You will often deal with numbers that are astronomically huge (like the distance to stars) or microscopically small (like the size of an atom). Writing these out with zeros is a nightmare, so we use Powers and Scientific Notation.

sections.heading: The Laws of Indices
sections.content:
Indices (or exponents) follow strict rules. If you master these three, you master the topic:
1. Multiplication: Add the powers ($x^a \times x^b = x^{a+b}$)
2. Division: Subtract the powers ($x^a \div x^b = x^{a-b}$)
3. Power of a Power: Multiply them ($(x^a)^b = x^{a \times b}$)

sections.heading: Real World Example
sections.content:
The speed of light is approximately $299,792,458$ m/s.
Scientific Notation: $2.998 \times 10^8$ m/s (approx).
